In recognition of this fact. Governor Brown proceeded early in his administration
to the reactivation of a Citizen's Advisory Committee on Educational Television
requesting the committee to make "a careful study of the entire educational
television situation as it now exists in California -- a study which would result
in recommendations for improvement which might be incorporated in legislative or
budget proposals to be presented to the 1961 session of the Legislature." On
June 11, 1959, letters were sent to nineteen citizens inviting them to serve on
this Committee, (Appendix B) and six days later, with acceptances from all nineÂ¬
teen, the Governor named James Day, General Manager of KQED, to serve as the
Committee Chairman. The initial meeting of the Committee occurred on January
9, 1960, in San Francisco, and the Committee continued to meet throughout the
year on a monthly basis.
The substance of the Committee's deliberations and study comprise the major part
of this report.
